- Parallel Exploration
- Discriminative Tests  
- Assumption Ledger
- Bayesian Updating
- Selective Pruning
- Hypothesis Slate

- Surprise as Signal

- The Two Axioms (Opus framing)

title: EPIC: Brenner Bot Lab v1 (brennerbot.org + bun binary)
description:
# North star
Build a *documents-first* multi-agent ‚Äúresearch lab‚Äù that operationalizes the **Brenner method** into repeatable workflows ‚Äî grounded in the Sydney Brenner transcript corpus ‚Äî and executed by a small research group of frontier-model coding agents.

This epic is the umbrella roadmap.

---

# Critical constraint (non-negotiable)
**No vendor AI APIs.**

We do *not* call OpenAI / Anthropic / Google model APIs from code. Instead, we coordinate:
- Codex CLI (GPT‚Äë5.2)
- Claude Code (Opus 4.5)
- Gemini CLI (Gemini 3)

‚Ä¶using subscription tiers (GPT Pro / Claude Max / Gemini Ultra) in terminal sessions.

---

# Core primitives (the architecture kernel)

## 1) Corpus (ground truth)
- Canonical primary source: `complete_brenner_transcript.md` with stable `¬ßn` anchors.
- Quote bank + curated primitives for high-signal grounding.

## 2) Protocol kernel (what ‚Äúgood‚Äù looks like)
- Canonical artifact schema (what a session must output).
- Structured delta format (mergeable updates, not essays).
- Guardrails (third alternative, potency checks, scale prison, provenance).

## 3) Coordination bus (durable, auditable)
- Agent Mail provides threads, inbox/outbox, acknowledgements, and file reservations.

## 4) Cockpit runtime (live parallelism)
- `ntm` is the recommended cockpit primitive for running multiple CLI agents in parallel in tmux.

## 5) Memory (compounding)
- `cass` for episodic search across agent sessions.
- `cass-memory (cm)` for procedural memory (rules + anti-patterns + confidence/decay), used as *optional* kickoff augmentation.

---

# The join-key contract (avoids chaos)
**Thread ID is the global join key** across:
- Agent Mail thread
- ntm session name
- any persisted session artifact path
- Beads issue ID (when applicable)

Preferred conventions:
- Engineering work: use the Beads ID as the Agent Mail `thread_id`.
- Research sessions: use a stable research key (e.g., `RS-YYYYMMDD-short-slug`).

---

# Deliverables (v1)

## Web app (brennerbot.org)
- Public mode: corpus/distillations/method docs only; **no orchestration side-effects**.
- Lab mode (gated): compose kickoffs, view session threads, compile/publish artifacts.

## CLI / single binary (`brenner`)
- Terminal-first workflows: compose ‚Üí send ‚Üí fetch ‚Üí compile ‚Üí publish.
- Builds to one portable executable via `bun build --compile`.

## Cockpit
- A documented, repeatable `ntm` workflow for multi-agent sessions.

---

# Definition of done (v1)
- Public site serves polished read-only corpus + distillations within the content policy.
- Lab mode can start a session and coordinate agents via Agent Mail (fail-closed if not enabled).
- Session compilation produces canonical artifact markdown that passes lint rules.
- CLI can run the same flow end-to-end and compile to a single executable.
- Operators have a runbook for local lab + cockpit usage.

---

# Risks / open questions
- Transcript redistribution rights (public vs gated): see brenner_bot-5so.7.6
- Orchestration security (tokens/secrets must not be exposed to public users).
- File sprawl vs durability (session artifacts must be explicit and minimal).
- Memory over-conditioning (default small, fail-soft, provenance labeled).

- kickoff
- agent delta response
- compiled artifact
- critique round
- operator/admin notes

- Thread status can be computed (who responded, latest artifact, missing acks).
- Compiler produces a canonical artifact that passes lint rules.
- Compiled artifact can be published back to the Agent Mail thread.

Brenner optimized for **evidence per week** and cheap, decisive moves.

A cockpit should:
- reduce context-switching overhead
- make parallel hypotheses cheap
- make it easy to compare representations across models
- keep the group honest (severe audience / third alternative)

---

- **ntm** (Named Tmux Manager): live parallelism (spawn panes, broadcast prompts, capture output)
- **Agent Mail threads**: durable coordination + audit trail
- **Thread ID join-key**: thread_id ‚Üî ntm session name ‚Üî artifact file naming

---

- Re-implement ntm inside Brenner Bot.
- Build vendor-API ‚Äúagent orchestration‚Äù.

---

- A documented cockpit runbook (operators can run a session without reading code).
- A session identity contract (thread id conventions; mapping to Beads IDs).
- Optional: a minimal `.ntm/` project template (prompt palette + helper commands) *if* it‚Äôs worth committing to repo.

---

- A new operator can:
  - start a session (create thread id, choose excerpt, send kickoff)
  - run 2‚Äì3 agents in parallel in ntm
  - get structured deltas back into the thread
  - compile/publish the canonical artifact
  - perform a clean wrap-up (persist artifacts, update memory optionally)

title: Epic: Full-Text Search
description:
Implement super-performant full-text 'search as you type' across all corpus documents.

## Context & Background

Current state:
- Basic search exists but ONLY for transcript sections (236 segments)
- Runtime parsing (no pre-built index) ‚Äî slow
- No search across distillations, quote bank, or metaprompts
- Missing: debouncing, highlighting, scope filtering

The corpus is ~589KB total (~68k words) across 7 documents. This is ideal for CLIENT-SIDE search ‚Äî no server round-trips needed.

## User Value

**Primary users**: Researchers looking for specific Brenner quotes, concepts, or passages
**Key scenarios**:
1. 'What did Brenner say about C. elegans?'
2. 'Find all mentions of exclusion testing'
3. 'Compare how different distillations discuss level-splitting'
4. Quick quote lookup for citations

## Goals

1. **Instant Results**: <50ms response time for any query
2. **Search as You Type**: Results update as user types (with debouncing)
3. **Full Corpus Coverage**: Search all documents, not just transcript
4. **Scope Filtering**: Option to search all docs OR just original transcripts
5. **Context Snippets**: Show matching text with surrounding context
6. **Highlighting**: Matched terms highlighted in results
7. **Keyboard Navigation**: Power users can navigate entirely via keyboard

## Anti-Goals

- NOT implementing server-side search (corpus is small enough for client-side)
- NOT adding fuzzy/semantic search (exact matching is fine for v1)
- NOT building advanced query syntax (simple keyword search)

## Technical Approach

**Recommended: FlexSearch** (lightweight, fast, supports partial matching)
- Build index at build time (not runtime)
- Include index in client bundle (~50-100KB compressed for this corpus)
- Use debounced input (150-200ms)
- Virtualize long result lists

Alternative considered: MiniSearch (smaller bundle, similar performance)

## Success Metrics

- Search response time < 50ms for any query
- Index size < 150KB compressed
- Zero perceived latency on type
- Works offline (index is client-side)

## Technical Considerations

- Integration with existing Command Palette (‚åòK)
- May extend or replace current transcript-only search
- Index needs to be rebuilt when corpus changes
- Consider lazy-loading index for faster initial page load

title: Feature: Search Infrastructure
description:
Build the core search infrastructure: index generation, storage, and query engine.

## Rationale

Before building UI, we need the search engine working. This is the foundation everything else depends on.

## Technical Decision: Client-Side Search

**Why client-side over server-side:**
- Corpus is small (~589KB text, ~68k words)
- Zero latency after initial load
- Works offline
- Simpler infrastructure (no search server)
- Fits in browser memory easily

**Library choice: FlexSearch**
- Fastest full-text search for JavaScript
- Supports partial matching and relevance scoring
- Small bundle size (~6KB gzipped core)
- Used by VS Code, Notion, others

Alternative: MiniSearch (smaller, good enough for our needs)

## Architecture

### Index Generation
- Run at BUILD TIME (not runtime)
- Parse all corpus documents
- Extract: title, content, section anchors, document type
- Output: JSON index file for client consumption

### Index Contents
For each searchable unit (section/paragraph):
```
{
  docId: string,
  docTitle: string,
  sectionId: string,
  sectionTitle: string,
  content: string,
  anchor: string (for linking)
}
```

### Query Engine
- Debounced search (150ms after typing stops)
- Return top N results with relevance scores
- Include context snippets around matches

## Deliverables

- Build-time index generation script
- Search index JSON file
- Client-side query engine wrapper
- Unit tests for search accuracy

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Index generated at build time
- [ ] Index includes all 7 corpus documents
- [ ] Search returns results in <50ms
- [ ] Relevance ranking works (exact matches higher)
- [ ] Index size < 150KB compressed
